bioghist.p: Henry Dilworth Gilpin (1801-1860) was an American lawyer and statesman of Quaker extraction who served as Attorney General of the United States. After graduating from the University of Pennsylvania, he studied law with Joseph R. Ingersoll and was admitted to the bar in 1822. He served as U.S. Attorney for the Eastern District of Pennsylvania from 1831 to 1837, and then as Solicitor of the United States Treasury in 1837. During this time he joined the American Philosophical Society and from 1833 to 1835 he was on the board of the Bank of the United States. President Martin Van Buren named him 14th Attorney General of the United States in 1840. He served until 1841, during which time he presented the U.S. government's side of the Amistad case to the U.S. Supreme Court. From 1853 until 1858 he was President of the Pennsylvania Academy of Fine Arts and from 1856 to 1858 he was a director of Girard College. He was also a secretary and director of the Chesapeake and Delaware Canal. Gilpin died in 1860.

scopecontent.p: This is a collection of papers of Henry D. Gilpin. Items include: a docket book involving Gilpin and other attorneys, 1818-1843; a scrapbook of clippings on legal cases, 1831-1833; a volume of Gilpin's notes on algebra and analytical geometry taken during his education at University of Pennsylvania, [after 1816]; and a letter of introduction to Levi Woodbury, Secretary of the Navy, written by H.D. Gilpin for James M. Broom Jr., dated 1833.

accessrestrict.p: The collection is open for research.
